As Yetkin writes, discussion will be focused on a transition to a "strengthened parliamentary system", though who knows if they'll even discuss a joint candidate in the presidential election. But equally important is what will they do on the economy? https://t.co/Jenjo35y0T

This is hilarious. The form of the discussion is of great importance writes @MuratYetkin2, adding: "What I mean by the ‚Äúform‚Äù is that they are basically talking about what kind of table that they are going to sit around, a rectangular or round?" Off to a great start I see.

Tbh that excites me way less than Saturday's meeting between leaders of Turkey's most dominant (?) political parties including the main opposition CHP. It's the first time they will all come together including ex-PM Davutoƒülu & ex-fin min Babacan.

There has been little said about a new constitution but it was reported last month a 15-article electoral law proposal was ready and would be submitted to parliament this month. It needs to be passed by June to come into force before the 2023 elections.

The Turkish publishing industry is also significantly impacted as @FulyaOzerkan writes. 

Kirmizi Kedi publishing house owner Haluk Hepkon says he fears all this uncertainty "will compel people to prioritise buying essentials and put aside buying books". https://t.co/T07GhBsnpX

Despite the presentation of the issue as one which only affects an "elite" who care about the exchange rate, the lira's devaluation hurts many since Turkey relies on imports. This story by @Grenadinere and I focuses on the impact on medicines https://t.co/aMWPNxvpxN

For Turkish President Erdoƒüan, it is about winning the "economic war of independence", pushing ahead with a plan for economic expansion through cheap exports. On Monday, he hailed a nearly 33% jump in exports to $225.36 billion. https://t.co/2dGgzCN6DX

Turkey's annual inflation rate surged to 36.08% in December, the highest since 2002. The lira - which was around 7 against the dollar in January 2021 - is worth around 13 today. (Don't even get me started on the GBP/TRY value). Money dominates every chat.

@achopkins1 I hadn't expected to spend seven hours in Ani (mostly because others said 3-4 hours was enough) but it was wonderful. So glad I could visit.

The city centre of Kars itself was lovely as well including the castle which dates back to the 12th century, and I had the famous kaz (goose, salty). We also visited the small Kars museum (from which the last 2 pictures were taken). I would definitely say Kars/Ani is a must-see. https://t.co/MhmH6CrNmz
Ani was just absolutely breath-taking, including the inside of the many churches of the city. https://t.co/GjNkIzjlNz

In August I went to Kars & visited the ruins of the medieval Armenian city of Ani on the border w/Armenia. We spent several hours exploring, able to visit what was once a busy city with perhaps as many as 100,000 residents during the 11th century. More via https://t.co/c5VQIAUpnc https://t.co/DNvqozoiU1

In July I went on a relaxing weekend to Eski≈üehir & the highlight was finally visiting the Odunpazarƒ± Modern M√ºze (OMM). We stayed at Tasigo where we often had the jacuzzi/hamam to ourselves. Another highlight was swimming in an outdoor pool in the rain with F-16s roaring above. https://t.co/NKtMGUuDmd

On the final day of the summit President Erdoƒüan pledged to send 15 million Covid vaccine doses to Africa, adding it was "disgraceful for humanity" that only 6% of Africans were vaccinated. African countries & Turkey also vowed to deepen their cooperation. https://t.co/kR1ZKnTLHB

In his opening speech, Turkish FM Mevl√ºt √áavu≈üoƒülu said 16 African leaders & 102 African ministers including 26 FMs were at the summit. "Our relations with Africa are strategic, long-term," he said, adding "concrete steps" will be taken on many areas including health & trade.

The Turkey-Africa Partnership Summit begins today and I‚Äôm tired just looking at this list of President Erdoƒüan‚Äôs meetings. One meeting at 1615 Turkish time is with Ethiopia‚Äôs Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed üëÄüëÄüëÄ https://t.co/3jNFLrnzlN

Ahead of the summit, I focused on the Turkish defence industry and its bid for a bigger market in Africa but back in October, I also wrote for @AFP  about the general focus on expanding trade relations. See thread here: https://t.co/Y2R71kbEJc

- And last but not least: health.

Turkey's health, education and agriculture ministers will also be attending and meeting their African counterparts for talks to further develop relations in those areas. African Union officials will also be there for the summit in ƒ∞stanbul.

President Erdoƒüan will speak on Saturday at the summit which African & Turkish officials prioritises:

- Peace, security and governance
- Trade, investment and security
- Education, science, technology & innovation/youth and women's development
- Infrastructure & agriculture

On Friday, Turkey will host dozens of African leaders, foreign ministers & other senior officials for the 3rd Turkey-Africa Partnership Summit over 2 days. I was told ~40 heads of state are expected, while 29 FMs confirmed they would attend. There will be bilateral meetings too.

The head of Turkey's Foreign Economic Relations Board, which hosted the October forum, insisted one must look beyond just hardware when focusing on Turkey's relations with Africa. "If we see the defence sector only as weapons, rockets, guns, tanks and rifles, it would be wrong."

"Now Turkey with drones has more cards to play when they have to bargain with other countries," Federico Donelli, international relations researcher at the University of Genoa, said after the Africa-Turkey eco forum in October. "This is a very good bargaining chip for Turkey." https://t.co/5kzTdP0vNV

There has been a lot of talk about Turkish drones and Ethiopia but a Western source told @AFP Turkey sent an undisclosed number of combat drones in support of Abiy Ahmed's campaign earlier this year, but Ankara has since responded to international pressure and halted the sales.

"Everywhere I go in Africa, everyone asks about drones," Turkish President Erdoƒüan proudly said after visiting his 29th and 30th African country in October.

Turkey's ties with Africa are interesting to watch, but particularly in terms of defence.
https://t.co/MbUMd9wJmM

There is also the Afrika Evi in Ankara, one of her initiatives. More info: https://t.co/gVkQrbFsbZ I hope to visit & will share images when I do.

Where a lot of Turkish foreign policy is reacting to events, Turkey has a long-term plan for Africa. While it goes back further, of note is the 1998 Africa Opening Action Plan. One event to watch is the Turkey-Africa summit in December, more political than last week's forum.

"Africa is no longer interested in aid, Africa is interested in investment," the Tanzania Industry and Trade Minister told one forum panel to rapturous applause. The phrase "win-win" kept coming up in interviews with African businesspeople as well as Turkish & African officials.

(Before the latest visits, Yeni ≈ûafak did a piece on which African countries Erdoƒüan has been to during this time in office as prime minister between 2003 and 2014, and as president between August 2014-present https://t.co/KAGLUbt5bq)

Look closely at Erdoƒüan's programmes and you will see many visits from African leaders. The latest was Chad's Mahamat Idriss Deby Itno on Wednesday, coming after the forum & Erdoƒüan's visits to Angola, Nigeria & Togo. (He's been to 30 African countries) https://t.co/oLmVjWfid5

From energy to infrastructure, agriculture to health, there are many areas where Turkish companies are working in African countries, and there are hopes for growth in those sectors. But of significance is defence, with expansion in ties expected, and even some drone sales.

When Turkish President Erdoƒüan became prime minister in 2003, Turkey's trade with Africa was worth $5.4bn. In 2020 it was worth $25.4bn. At last week's Turkey-Africa Economic and Business Forum, Erdoƒüan said he wanted to see this rise to $50bn, then $75bn. https://t.co/1Ss5iR1jZq

NASA said in February that Lake Salda in SW Turkey (Burdur) "is the only known lake on Earth that contains carbonate minerals and depositional features (deltas) similar to those found at Jezero Crater, which is thought to have once contained a lake." https://t.co/CrLO67Oca3

Why is it at risk? Well because of its popularity. Campaigners, lawyers & geology experts said the lake will be damaged by too much of the wrong kind of tourism. They propose observation towers for people to just view the lake, but right now, in some areas, you can swim in it.

NASA believes Lake Salda could provide clues to Mars. But in a visit with @dirkaDemir & @Kilicbil this month, we discovered regardless of the Mars link, it's a very special lake with its own ecosystem & endemic species. Campaigners warn this is at risk.

For @Turkeyrecap, I did a series of graphics in October to illustrate the trade relationship between Turkey & the EU. https://t.co/ZUsWldjQ4o

Turkey's parliamentary system transformed into an executive presidency in 2018, & with that has been a lot of change. EU reminded Ankara of its obligation to align competition & state aid rules with the bloc. Turkey said the state aid authority was currently being restructured.

One of Ankara's longstanding requests has been for Turkey's consideration in third-party free trade agreements since what is decided affects the country. During the meeting, Turkey said its CU relationship & interest should be considered during the Brexit process and in US talks.

The same website provides a report from a meeting of the EU-Turkey Customs Union joint committee in Brussels in July 2019. During the meeting, Turkey sought the delisting of certain Turkish products from certain regulations.
https://t.co/IZ6wOAz70X

The CU came into force in December 1995 & covers all industrial goods, but doesn't address agriculture (except for processed agricultural products), services or public procurement. It was in Dec. 2016 that Brussels proposed to modernise the CU. All via https://t.co/CCqTTdC9ln

Turkey repeatedly calls for the updating of the Customs Union with the EU. Like in Sept., √áavu≈üoƒülu brought up the longstanding issue, saying Turkey expected "concrete steps" to be taken ahead of an EU summit https://t.co/Eik42lsvX4

https://t.co/ecgPhfAhRQ 

(This thread explores üáπüá∑-üá´üá∑ ties https://t.co/7hlnUK7h2d)

In 2020, the list of issues causing problems for üáπüá∑-üá™üá∫ relations was long:

In the last months of 2016, the üáπüá∑-üá™üá∫ relationship - already not great after the March 2016 refugee deal - deteriorated following the failed coup. Turkey's foreign policy, viewed as aggressive, added further strains as Ankara launched offensives in Syria. https://t.co/0LCIUxWPKf

Turkish President Erdoƒüan & √áavu≈üoƒülu had meetings with EU ambassadors on Jan. 12. The Turkish leader said üáπüá∑ had "never given up on full membership, which is our ultimate goal, despite all the double standards & injustices we have faced in this process."

Key dates in üáπüá∑-üá™üá∫ relations:

1963 - Ankara Association Agreement was signed
1987 - üáπüá∑ applied to join the "European Economic Community"
1995 - Customs Union established

Belgian journalist @SarahLamote (an absolute wonder) has been a leading force on this subject in Europe and we've periodically discussed the issue so I want to share her work. https://t.co/bGcIuncQRf

And for the Brits, there is more detail about British plastics ending up in Turkey via this link from the BBC earlier this year: https://t.co/HMSbtvzYUs

One thing that was really stressed to me, and which @POLITICOEurope covered well recently, was how much we needed to move away from relying on recycling to justify our consumption, especially of plastics. I recommend reading this https://t.co/22aLFufgQR

In September, the environment ministry said the recycling industry must source a maximum of 50% of what it needs through imports while the rest had to be sourced domestically. Parliament also last week passed a bill to set up an environment agency. https://t.co/Cx2CsvPTHZ)

Alongside these issues, Turkey is striving to develop its waste collection system while First Lady Emine Erdogan leads a #zerowaste movement since 2017. Last year a Zero Waste Blue Project launched while Turkey banned plastic bags at the start of 2019. https://t.co/DyTd707m6r

GAMA Recycle chairman Zafer Kaplan told AFP even if Turkey collected all of its waste, there would still be a need to import. Mehmet Dasdemir, of GAMA Recycle, insisted the company's efforts was "good for the environment" because the material would not decompose if left alone.

But there are companies like GAMA Recycle which import plastic bottles from the US and Europe and turn it into fibre and thread, some of which is used by H&M, Zara, Ikea and Turkish fashion retailers like LC Waikiki. Some pictures from that process in Gaziantep taken last month. https://t.co/C9bOnzB7pm

There are other European countries' plastics as well, including France. Images my own from Adana again. @gundogdu_sedat0 told AFP last month European citizens needed to think carefully about where the recycling they carefully separate ends up. https://t.co/LDGSBEz2NB

There's more! Even came across a 1995 romance novel called Steamy December, copies of @MetroUK, McCain chips & @CostaCoffee packaging. My photos. 

What I haven't yet mentioned is some of this ends as microplastics in rivers or burned, sending hazardous chemicals into the air. https://t.co/0ozipKOF6C

Calling attention especially to Brits! I came across plastic packaging for baked beans, @sainsburys Taste the Difference products, and @ASOS and @Debenhams bags used for online orders. The images were taken in Adana, in southern Turkey, from different dumping sites. https://t.co/Euo0DrdMaS

But the issue is tonnes of the plastic packaging ends up in rivers, ditches and roadsides of southern Turkey, as these pictures taken last month in Adana show. We went to multiple sites and found similar images. The next couple of tweets will be a closer look at these areas. https://t.co/vR6NhAVG4n

According to @EU_Eurostat via @Greenpeace_Med, in 2019, the monthly average plastic imports increased to 48,500 tonnes from around 4,000 in 2016. The top 5 exporters to Turkey in 2019 were the UK, Italy, Belgium, Germany and France. https://t.co/JOhnNF8V9f https://t.co/MRgxzxGlwe

What happens to Europeans plastics when it is exported by countries including the UK & France to Turkey? We have another weekend lockdown (the one time I finally organised a coffee outside!) 

But from Monday, Turkey is relaxing a lot of restrictions in place since March including:

- Reopening restaurants, cafes, sports facilities, daycare centres (though schools shut until Sept)

Those I've spoken to on this all agreed on one thing: the risk of a second wave is real & so we must continue to do what we're doing so far: socially distance, wear masks at all times outside & wash our hands regularly.
(I was tempted to say #stayalert lol but that wasn't said)

Turkey's mortality rate is 2.8%. Ofc a point made often is the the death toll figures (FT covered best imho https://t.co/LnBlMbwafz), especially in light of the Turkish Medical Association's criticism of how officials count deaths, which TMA says doesn't follow all of WHO's codes

Turkey's response: "Syrian Regime parliament resolution recognizing the incidents of 1915 as so-called genocide provides a grim example in itself. It's the picture of the hypocrisy of a regime which has indulged in every kind of carnage towards its own people including children." https://t.co/o56lf9RqE8

The article also notes how the French failed to collect intelligence within Turkey in contrast to Turkey's knowledge of Syria in this period. The French authorities relied on individuals and groups who crossed the border like refugees, merchants and even smugglers among others.

The French resisted at first, but then some Armenian families were later accused of being involved in smuggling and "were forcibly resettled in the interior." The removal was "sporadic and selective", the author writes.

When Turkish press referred to "wild" rumours of a French endorsement to the establishment of an autonomous Armenian province in the early 1930s, Turkey asked the Mandate authorities to remove thousands of Armenians from the border area.

The article says French intelligence suspected that high-ranking Turkish officials "never abandoned the idea of regaining Syrian provinces despite the on-going diplomatic negotiations around the delimitation of the international boundary between Turkey and France."

Tejel says the "study of the webs of rumors both originating from and concerning the Turkish-Syrian border helps provide an alternative narrative about the border-making and state formation processes in the interwar Middle East."
This journal article from Jordi Tejel focuses on the rumours of "imminent annexation of Northern Syria by Turkey in the interwar years". https://t.co/w6dkZ6bxoB

Again, another observation from the first research paper I mentioned, "However, the rate of those who do not think that vaccination is beneficial was significantly higher in regions with a high socioeconomic level (Marmara, Mediterranean, Aegean Sea, and Central Anatolia)."

"A growing number of Muslims believe that vaccines contain pork, which is forbidden in Islam. The other group is secular and typically well-educated, who often believe that vaccines contain harmful substances like aluminum or mercury."

It's worth reading the paper I linked to in my first tweet, not too long. There's also this from @pritheworld which is a good read https://t.co/Lc4FIbawws

The vaccination issue has managed to heal the secular-Muslim divide (please note the tone of this remark including the pun).

But please note that 6.57% of these participants considered vaccines "non-beneficial". Why? The two main reasons were:
- I do not trust vaccine companies
- I heard it was harmful from the TV
and the internet

In a sample of 1,004 people, the researchers found: (direct quotes)
- A significantly higher number of females than males stated that vaccines are non-beneficial
- A larger proportion of highly educated participants than those less educated stated that
vaccines are non-beneficial

To go back to the paper, the authors note a 2% decrease in the vaccine rate in Turkey between 2016-2018, & note, "this decline may continue". "We found that individuals who are hesitant are more likely to have a higher socioeconomic status, income level, and education level."

There is a chance I failed during my keyword search of this document but I will share this document because it's very exciting to find. The health ministry publishes a health statistics yearbook annually, in English and in Turkish. Very useful. https://t.co/0yiGLPZKAH

RT @RazAkkoc: After my excitement of Is Bank died down, I realised there was another bank's (Ziraat) museum nearby in a building also by Gi‚Ä¶

There is plenty of information on things like how the logo developed as well as old objects like cheque books, stamps and piggy banks. The last photograph shows objects belonging to former PM Adnan Menderes, who was killed following the 1960 coup. https://t.co/OZ7EONRjT4

It dates back to the Ottoman period. Ziraat means agriculture so you can safely guess the link between farmers & the bank. Mithat Pasha founded Homeland Funds which is the foundation of today's bank. The link has details on how it came into being in 1863. https://t.co/7ReTG4sZtZ https://t.co/HXBMHz2LrL

I discovered this in the 1st half of 2019 but the museum was closed for refurbishment until late 2019 (it recently opened when I visited on Dec 24). It was the first bank museum, they proudly tell visitors, & opened in 1981. Warning: there's a lot to read & see there but worth it https://t.co/MTW4FNIi5h

After my excitement of Is Bank died down, I realised there was another bank's (Ziraat) museum nearby in a building also by Giulio Mongeri in Ulus. The building housing the museum was completed in 1929. More on the history: https://t.co/AwmYRCs3ac
https://t.co/a8SDe7IVEj https://t.co/EpROZbibjS

What I was able to see included Ulu Camii. Later I didn't take a pic but a particularly poignant moment was visiting the 4-legged minaret in the old city by which Kurdish human rights lawyer Tahir Elci was shot dead. He was calling for an end to fighting. https://t.co/TWvMkN8t91 https://t.co/br4Ypb7oMx

I then went to Diyarbakir for the first time (I know, shameful delay). I was unable to enter parts of the old city, Sur. For context on what happened in 2015 & 2016 in the region: https://t.co/bF0fl8Rth7

For background on the Kurdish issue, this is good:
https://t.co/jiDEKHZloe

Meanwhile, the Culture and Art Union stated that some of the employees at the Zeugma Mosaic Museum had previously been subjected to mobbing and that some employees had also filed lawsuits. (From @HDNER)

"Mobbing" is a new concept recognized by the Turkish legal system.  Literally, mobbing means bullying of an individual by a group in any context, such as a family, friends, peers, school, workplace, neighborhood, community, or online. 

From 2017 

https://t.co/6aYwdiFpIG

If anyone asks me what really surprised me living in Turkey, it's the workplace bullying issue. Everyone has an anecdote or three. (Before anyone chips in to add to say they knew, I never lived in Turkey pre-2016 nor did my mother work here until she came a few years before me)

Aslƒ± Pasinli, the family lawyer. said that they would demand an extension of the investigation into whether she was suicidal as a result of long-term workplace bullying.

The suspect faces life imprisonment for "deliberately killing with monstrous feeling" if convicted. He has previously tried to suggest his actions were provoked because Bulut had insulted him. The trial was adjourned to October 21.

Towards the end of her testimony, she told the court: "He is not my father." Afterwards, the judge decided to play the video & the hearing descended into chaos with members of Bulut's family attacking the defendant. Dozens were told to leave the small, packed courtroom by police.

The killer, the daughter said, didn't allow her to leave on a bus and so they went to a donerci nearby and "what happened happened there", she said. When the judge asked her if she tried to stop her father, she said: "I threw my bag, I threw my tablet, but I couldn't stop him."

The suspect's lawyer told the court that Bulut went to a police station to make a complaint against him a couple of hours before she was killed, saying it could amount to negligence on the part of the police.

She told the court how the killer had caused trouble for the mother and daughter earlier in the day, and that even at one point they went to the police station. She did not give more information about what happened there as she was in another room.

The most powerful testimony which had the lawyers, supporters and journalists in the courtroom in tears was from the 10-year-old daughter via video. When the judge said, "your father", she replied: "Let's say that person" (O ki≈üi in Turkish).

Bulut's mother Fadime, who at one point was overwhelmed with emotions and had to leave the courtroom briefly in Kirikkale, tearfully said during the hearing that she wanted the killer to "get the harshest sentence". I should note that the killer used his right to remain silent.

I didn't get a chance to share the testimony at the time from the trial during which family members spoke in court including the 10-year-old who was not there in person, and who in the video shared online in August said to her mother: "Mum, please don't die."

On Oct 9, the trial began into the murder of Emine Bulut. She was killed by her ex-husband in front of her 10yo in August. The killing sparked anger in Turkey after a video was posted online showing Bulut screaming to her daughter: "I don't want to die." https://t.co/wmk5QkPfju

Then on Monday, the AKP's executive committee agreed to send Davutoglu to a disciplinary board for dismissal after Erdogan's remarks on Saturday in Davutoglu's hometown of Konya. He had said "politics is not done through threats" as he appeared to signal what was to come.

How did Erdogan respond? On Friday, he said: "These friends should say everything they have to say. There can be no threat with these kinds of words... there's benefit in making public whatever they have... we have no concerns... Don't forget, art is long and life is short."

What does he mean? Well, that he's targeting some officials from the AKP, from the Nationalist Movement Party (MHP) and the pro-Kurdish Peoples' Democratic Party (HDP), based on sources speaking to BBC Turkce. https://t.co/Nsz5iZMUjP

Davutoglu added, "In the future when the history of Turkey is written, I am sure one of the most critical periods will be between June 7-November 1." That period is when the ceasefire with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed & when there were multiple terror attacks.

More drama came after Davutoglu reportedly said, "If the fight against terror is investigated many people won't be able to show their face. Those criticising us today won't be able to go out in public."

Someone has registered the name of the Life and Justice Party (any Gilmore Girls fan will understand why I always end this with 'Life and Death Brigade' in my head), (Yas ve Adalet Parti in Turkish, YAP, which means "do"). Some wordplay there. But who? We don't know.

Until Wednesday (Aug 28) when media reported that Sadullah Ergin had resigned from the ruling AKP. (Apparently he quietly resigned earlier than this). There were reports of other resignations but Ergin was confirmed. https://t.co/CvlSbvUZIp

From a mix of sources, the names linked to Babacan include ex-deputy premier Besir Atalay, ex-justice minister Sadullah Ergin, ex-constitutional court chief Ha≈üim Kƒ±lƒ±√ß. Others include ex-education minister Huseyin Celik and Nihat Ergun, ex-minister of science. None confirmed.

The plans are in motion reportedly. According to one source linked to Babacan, the latter's party could be launched in Dec. (https://t.co/tDfktPmrJy). Then there are reports Davutoglu has already rented a 3-storey building for his party's HQ in Ankara. (https://t.co/FRlIL47ysR)

Erdogan told journalists in July that he said to Babacan that the latter didn't have the right to "break up the ummah" (Muslim community). The president added they disagreed over interest rates. "For us, the common cause should not be abandoned," he said. https://t.co/rO5ZnNtuH2

Babacan resigned from President Erdogan's ruling AKP on July 8, citing "deep differences" over policy. Babacan met with Erdogan before this resignation, and reportedly told him of his plans to resign and the new party. https://t.co/gDMnqCMWRl

And Gul? He's the former president who had co-founded the ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP) with Erdogan and others. He was foreign minister before president. Since his time as president ended in 2014, there are persistent rumours he will return to the political stage.

And Davutoglu? Non-Turkey watchers will know him very well from his time as prime minister and the EU-Turkey deal in 2016. He served as foreign minister after working as Erdogan's chief advisor. He was pushed out as premier in May 2016 after relations with Erdogan went downhill.

Who is Babacan? He has also served as deputy premier, foreign minister and was previously AKP MP for Ankara. He stopped serving in the government in 2015. A point often made is that he was the youngest member of the first AKP government in 2002. https://t.co/mLTilO5gPN

In July I wrote about how Erdogan's former allies have decided 17 years into AKP rule, they will stick their head above the parapet, throw their hat in the ring [insert own cliche]. Whether Davutoglu sets up his party is less certain if rumours are true https://t.co/xmqlAMHam8

Is Turkey about to get a new political party? Well, perhaps literally the party will be new but the actors, less so. The never-ending rumours are that Ali Babacan, ex-economy minister, and former president Abdullah Gul will set up a party, and so will ex-premier Ahmet Davutoglu.

ƒ∞dris √ñzyol, a journalist from Antalya in the south, was the 2nd to be attacked on May 15 outside his paper's offices. The 3rd to be attacked was Ergin Cevik, in Antalya on May 20. Then 4th incident was Denizli's shooting while he was taking his grandchild to daycare on May 24.

Then Demiraƒü was briefly jailed last month for insulting Erdogan for an old conviction, one of many cases he has faced. "Being a journalist in Turkey is hard, attacking journalists is heroic," he said during an interview in May.

The first was Yavuz Selim Demiraƒü, a columnist for the nationalist Yenicag paper, who was beaten on May 10 by 6 using baseball bats. When asked why, he pointed to an ad put out by the Nationalist Movement Party (MHP) listing journalists' names after the 2018 vote including his.

There are some beautiful meeting rooms in the building's other floors though my photographs don't do them justice. There is some more information on the bank's Wiki page which describes the other floors that I intend to visit soon too https://t.co/j0APQ2SNpj https://t.co/FMd4BQcY1Y

This map shows where the bank's branches were in Turkey, but the bank also had branches in Hamburg and Alexandria, established in 1932. The former was subsequently closed during WW2 but another set were opened from 1955 starting with Nicosia. (Info in TR https://t.co/fprnOCFCD4) https://t.co/fwkztIwioI

The bank invested in many sectors including sugar, glass, coal, cotton as well as cultural endeavours like cinemas. There was also a focus on establishing an insurance provider. This fabulous "Sigorta Korur (insurance protects)" statue is on show. Reminds me of Lord Buckethead. https://t.co/pDEUmq2L0B

There is an exhibition on the bank's history on the same floor with biographical details of the founders of Is Bank including its first general manager, Celal Bayar. Bayar served as the republic's 3rd president between 1950-1960. More about him here: https://t.co/DH6ucEiZCg https://t.co/zCn0XJ6M3t

On the ground floor, which is a replica of how it would have looked in its early days (staff there said), there are papers from the bank's early years including chequebooks, laws to protect "Turk parasi" (Turkish money) & posters encouraging citizens to open accounts, save money. https://t.co/Z1U4Jmaobu

So the opening of a new museum (always a welcome thing in Ankara) filled me with utter delight and I had the chance to go inside on Sunday where I learned a lot about the bank's prominence in the history of the republic (founded in 1923). The bank itself was established in 1924. https://t.co/32Z7xeypJR

Last week Turkey's Is Bank opened the Economic Independence Museum in the bank's historic & beautiful building in Ulus, Ankara (built in 1929). The architect was Giulio Mongeri, a Levantine of Italian extraction. Since I arrived here, it has been one of my favourite buildings. https://t.co/iM4aJ0wZsI

Turkey is stuck between a rock & a hard place, experts say. Upsetting Russia could be viewed by Ankara as carrying greater risk with regards to its Idlib agreement to avoid a regime offensive or losing Russian tourists. In 2018, 6 million Russians came to Turkey, up 26% from 2017

Turkish Defence Minister Hulusi Akar last month said Ankara expected delivery of the F-35s in November to Malatya in the east, though of course this was before last night's decision. The S-400 delivery is expected in July, say Turkish officials. Source https://t.co/aCiMSjjqsY

Turkey had planned to buy 100 F-35A fighter jets, with pilots already training in the US. The plane's manufacturer, Lockheed Martin, said that contracts with Turkish companies to build parts for the F-35 had been expected to reach $12 billion. Via @AFP in Washington.

"Until they forgo delivery of the S-400, the United States has suspended deliveries and activities associated with the stand-up of Turkey's F-35 operational capability," Pentagon chief spokesman Charles E. Summers Jr. said in the statement. https://t.co/Ixa8xYJB9W

Last night the US it was halting all deliveries and joint work with Turkey on the F-35 jet programme. "Should Turkey procure the S-400, their continued participation in the F-35 programme is at risk." You can read more in @AFP's story from Washington here. https://t.co/Ixa8xYJB9W

The S-400 deal risks sanctions by Washington under the Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act (CAATSA), but Turkish FM Mevlut Cavusoglu said the deal was signed before the law was passed. He said last week Turkey wouldn't be selling the system to a "3rd" country.

The Americans offered Turkey the Patriot with the condition that they would back away from the S-400 deal. There was an apparent deadline for March 31 to respond to the US offer but Cavusoglu has said recently that Patriot negotiations had begun. https://t.co/cqm5ooUXcV

"We agreed a deal with Russia on the S-400, so for us to turn back from the deal is out of the question," Erdogan said in Feb. Turkey's push to buy the system has caused tensions with Washington, already affected by US support for the YPG and other issues. https://t.co/0xDKVaaCSS

Turkey signed a deal with Russia to buy the S-400 air defence missile system. Although President Erdogan insists the deal is "done", the US hopes Ankara will not buy the system, which US officials say "won't be NATO interoperable". Thus TR's juggling the 2 https://t.co/cqm5ooUXcV

@LuanaSarmini Now the ex-workers have reached a deal with Flormar and they will receive compensation, which varies according to how long they worked at the factory. They cannot return to the factory to work there. For more, read @LuanaSarmini's piece from Oct (French) https://t.co/H3ED7530oU

@LuanaSarmini spoke to Rocher in October who said the claims were "totally false because, based on what the group was able to identify in exchanges with the local management, there were no firings based on trade union membership or because of having supporting different actions."

Then four months later, 47 other workers lost their job and the protests continued, under banners and messages calling for a boycott of Yves Rocher, the main brand of the French cosmetics group which is a majority shareholder of Flormar since 2012.

They had been protesting in front of the former cosmetics factory in a bid to return to work, which they claimed to have lost because of trade union activities. In mid-May 2018, 85 out of around 400 workers at the factory had been sacked -- the majority of whom were women.

After 297 days of daily protests outside their ex-workplace, a factory of Flormar which is a brand of Yves Rocher, dozens of the former employees have ended their protest in Gebze, east of Istanbul, reports @LuanaSarmini. "The Flormar resistance won," said ex-worker Nurhan Guler.

And what about violence against women? Last Nov, the interior minister said in the first 10 months of 2018, over 96k women reported violence while it was 133k in 2017. He added in the past 19 months, 393 women were killed, lower than We Will Stop Femicide's figure of 440 for 2018

As academic Feride Acar said re a perceived increase in reported violence against women, "there is a seemingly an increase in incidents but we cannot prove that with actual numbers because statistics.. is not really reliable, and it's not there to cover all the incidents."

To make it clear, the CHP is Turkey's main opposition party. In another report by deputy leader Gamze Akkus, the party claims there has been a 67% increase in sexual abuse of female children. (When it comes to increase in figures, one must remember we see more reporting today)

The CHP's @SuzanSahin1881 published a report today on women in Turkey. She is a member of the parliamentary committee on equality of opportunity for women and men. She says 41% of women working are in "precarious" work while 37% of 3 million public sector personnel are women.

And the situation re work? The Turkish Statistics Office on Weds said the employment rate for women was 28.9% compared with 65.6% for men. Turkstat found "the higher the education status of females, the more they participated in the labour force". Data:  https://t.co/uWKUj9MUo2

In 1935, 4.52% of the assembly were women, now it's 17.1% after 2018 elex. Link: https://t.co/WbHMBZUOxA https://t.co/BAdMPXY9fP

A government study from 2014 conducted in coordination with Hacettepe University found that 38 percent of women have been subjected to either physical and/or sexual violence at any point in their lives. The full report in English can be found here: https://t.co/M0pEct9MgD

Interior Minister Suleyman Soylu on Wednesday said the number of women killed for every one million fell since 2016. It was 5 in 2015, in 2018 it was 3.4. In November, Soylu said over 96k women were victims of violence in the first 10 months of 2018 compared with 133k+ in 2017.

Issue of gender equality is of concern to GREVIO, who note claims from NGOs that "necessary financial means to enhance women‚Äôs status & promote their empowerment are being re-directed in support of family-oriented policies which
do little to decrease women‚Äôs economic dependency."

The report also focused on the "heightened risk of violence" for Kurdish women in the southeast who may fear reporting violence. There is a longer sentence on the "harassment, sexual violence and threats" claims in the southeast from the report below. https://t.co/ikFTSsP3gn

"Nobody wants violence", Acar said, but the link between gender inequality & violence is not accepted. GREVIO said it was "extremely concerned that policy makers in Turkey might be willing to turn a blind eye to violence against women out of their desire to promote family unity".

Acar is president of the Council of Europe's Group of Experts on Action against Violence against Women and Domestic Violence, which monitors the convention's enforcement. Their latest report came out in October 2018, which you can find here (136 pages) https://t.co/0AG3oDGmAI

But Feride Acar, Turkish academic, who also contributed to the convention's text, said reporting of violence against women has increased, but we don't have the data to make comparisons over time. "There is not nearly enough reporting but it is still more than what it used to be."

How much violence takes place? Well the figures we have may not show the real picture. In 2018, the women's rights group We Will Stop Femicide said 440 women were killed in 2018, it was 210 in 2012. But Interior Minister Suleyman Soylu yesterday suggested data shows it is falling

But academics and activists say police and judiciary personnel need more training to ensure women are aware of the rights they have if they are a victim of violence. For example, lawyer Gunce Cetin said sometimes police do not remind women they have a right to a lawyer as well.

Turkey has ratified the Istanbul convention, the world's most progressive binding accord to prevent and combat violence against women. After this, law 6284 was passed in Turkey in 2012.  Activists praise the law, the text of which is in the link below. https://t.co/IzeLLHs99b

According to NTV, Sƒ±la told the court she suffered "violence for an hour" during the hearing also attended by a lawyer for the family, labour and social services ministry. The trial resumes on April 22. (Those who speak Turkish can read NTV's article) https://t.co/Q6idjPEIrw)

The case is significant in a patriarchal society where many believe such issues should remain in the private sphere (and yes, Turkey is not alone in conservative attitudes prevailing so don't apply whataboutism here) while many women are not aware of laws which do protect them.
